Spirometry [Internet]. [date unknown];[cited 2010 Aug 25 ] Available from: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirometry

Pingul EM, de Guia TS, Ayuyao FG. FEV1/FEV6 VS FEV1/FVC IN THE SPIROMETRIC DIAGNOSIS OF AIRWAYS OBSTRUCTION AMONG ASIANS. In: Chest Meeting Abstracts. 2007 p. 491c.
Tiffeneau R, Pinelli A. Air circulant et air captif dans l'exploration de la fonction ventilatrice pulmonaire. Paris Med 1947;133:624-8.

details.purpose: To record the results of a common suite of pulmonary function measurements and calculated ratios to assess lung volumes, airway function and gas exchange.
details.use:
Use to record measurements of lung volumes, airway function and gas exchange, commonly as part of a suite of measurements and calculations known as a pulmonary function test, including spirometry.
Multiple events and state information may be used to capture multiple measurements, pre- and post-bronchial challenge or bronchodilation results.
details.misuse:
Not to be used to record the results of blood gas tests. Use the OBSERVATION.laboratory_test_result for this purpose.
Not to be used to record measurements about pulse oximetry. Use the OBSERVATION.pulse_oximetry for this purpose.

details.purpose: *To record results of pulmonary function tests, including spirometry and lung volume testing. (en)
details.use: *Used to record all representations of pulmonary function testing, including spirometry. Multiple events and state information may be used to capture pre and post bronchial challenge or bronchodilation results. (en)
details.misuse: *Supporting subject information, often required to interpret the tests, such as smoking status or oxygenation, should be captured in separate, specific archetypes.(en)

items.items: The results of a common suite of pulmonary function measurements and calculated ratios to assess lung volumes, airway function and gas exchange.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The time taken to complete a forced expiration.
Details of the device used to measure pulmonary function.
A test of the diffusion capacity (DLCO), or transfer factor (TLCO), of the lung for carbon monoxide (CO).
Also called carbon monoxide diffusing capacity test. Generally DLCO is measured in "ml/min/kPa" and TLCO is measured in "ml/min/mmHg".
The ratio of actual to predicted test result.
Details of any bronchial challenge administered as part of the test.
The agent or physical modality used e.g exercise.
The dose of agent used in the test.
Details of bronchodilation administered as part of the test.
The bronchodilating agent used in the test.
Test result represented as a measured volume or calculated capacity.
A calculated test result expressed as a ratio.
Test result represented as a measured flow rate.
The amount of air that can be forced out of the lungs after a maximal inspiration. Emphasis on completeness of expiration. Also termed expiratory vital capacity (EVC) Calculated= IRV+ Vt+ ERV.
The volume change of the lung between a full inspiration to total lung capacity and a maximal expiration to residual volume.
The volume of gas contained in the lung after a full inhalation.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in one second.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in three seconds.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in six seconds.
The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in 0.75 of a second.
The maximum flow generated during expiration performed with maximal force and started after a full inspiration. Also termed Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR).
The average flow of air from the lung during the middle portion (25-75%) of expiration (also sometimes referred to as the MMEF, for maximal mid-expiratory flow).
The average flow of air from the lung during the middle portion (25-50%) of expiration (also sometimes referred to as the MMEF, for maximal mid-expiratory flow).
The average flow of air into the lung during the middle portion (25-75%) of inspiration.
The average flow of air into the lung during the middle portion (25-50%) of inspiration.
The maximal volume that can be inspired following a normal expiration. Also termed Inspiratory vital capacity (IVC). Calculated = TV+IRV.
The amount of additional air that can be pushed out after the end expiratory level of normal breathing.
The additional air that can be inhaled after a normal tidal breath in.
A measure of the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled and exhaled in one minute. Also termed Maximum ventilation per minute.
The ratio of Forced Expiratory volume in 1 second to Inspired vital capacity. Calculated = FEV1/ IVC.
The ration of Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to Forced vital capacity.
The volume of air inspired and then expired from the lung during one respiratory cycle.
The amount of air left in the lungs after a maximal exhalation.
The amount of air left in the lungs after a tidal breath out. Calculated = ERV+RV.
The name of the volume test.
The name of the flow rate test.
The name of the calculated ratio.
Details of the agent used in the test.
The test was taken before the challenge.
The test was performed after the bronchial challenge.
The timing of the test in relation to the challenge.
Record any issues or factors that may impact on the measurement of pulmonary function tests.
Additional narrative about the test results and intepretation not captured in other fields.
The body position of the individual at the time of measurement.
Standing at the time of measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of measurement.
Reclining at the time of measurement.
Lying flat at the time of measurement.
The ratio of actual to predicted test result.
The pulmonary function test result is not available.
The reason why the pulmonary function test result is not available.
The volume of the conducting airways.
Overall clinical interpretation about all of the measurements and calculated ratios.
Digital representation of the test results.
For example: Flow volume loop; or volume-time tracing.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Details to explicitly record that this test was not performed.
The pulmonary function test result is not available.
The reason why the pulmonary function test result is not available.
*Pulmonary function testing including spirometry and other lung volume testing.(en)
*The time taken to complete a forced expiration. (en)
*Details of the device used to measure pulmonary function.(en)
*A test of the diffusion capacity (DLCO), or transfer factor (TLCO), of the lung for carbon monoxide (CO).

*Also called carbon monoxide diffusing capacity test. Generally DLCO is measured in "ml/min/kPa" and TLCO is measured in "ml/min/mmHg". In North America the unit is mL/min/mmHg. The Systeme Internationale unit is mmol/min/kPa. The following equation converts between the 2 units: D, 2.986 X T (en)
*The ratio of actual to predicted test result.(en)
*Details of any bronchial challenge administered as part of the test.(en)

*A calculated test result expressed as a ratio. (en)
*Test result represented as a measured flow rate. (en)
*The amount of air that can be forced out of the lungs after a maximal inspiration. Emphasis on completeness of expiration. Also termed expiratory vital capacity (EVC) Calculated= IRV+ Vt+ ERV.(en)
*The volume change of the lung between a full inspiration to total lung capacity and a maximal expiration to residual volume.(en)
*The volume of gas contained in the lung after a full inhalation.(en)
*The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in one second.(en)
*The amount of air that can be forcibly blown out in three seconds.(en)

*The maximum flow generated during expiration performed with maximal force and started after a full inspiration. Also termed Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR).(en)
*The average flow of air from the lung during the middle portion (25-75%) of expiration (also sometimes referred to as the MMEF, for maximal mid-expiratory flow).(en)
*The average flow of air from the lung during the middle portion (25-50%) of expiration (also sometimes referred to as the MMEF, for maximal mid-expiratory flow).(en)
*The average flow of air into the lung during the middle portion (25-75%) of inspiration.(en)
*The average flow of air into the lung during the middle portion (25-50%) of inspiration.(en)
*The maximal volume that can be inspired following a normal expiration. Also termed Inspiratory vital capacity (IVC). Calculated = TV+IRV.(en)
*The amount of additional air that can be pushed out after the end expiratory level of normal breathing.(en)
*The additional air that can be inhaled after a normal tidal breath in.(en)
*A measure of the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled and exhaled in one minute. Also termed Maximum ventilation per minute.(en)
*The ratio of Forced Expiratory volume in 1 second to Inspired vital capacity. Calculated = FEV1/ IVC.(en)
*The ration of Forced expiratory volume in 1 second to Forced vital capacity.(en)
*The volume of air inspired and then expired from the lung during one respiratory cycle.(en)
*The amount of air left in the lungs after a maximal exhalation.(en)
*The amount of air left in the lungs after a tidal breath out. Calculated = ERV+RV.(en)
